item.title: Serbia Arrests Dozens After Clashes at Anti-Government Rally
item.description: Serbian police clashed with anti-government protesters after tens of thousands rallied in Belgrade demanding an early election to remove President Aleksandar Vucic and his governing party.
item.dc:creator: Misha Savic

media:content.media:description: A flare burns as Serbian Riot Police move towards protesters as tens of thousands gather in central Belgrade to issue an "ultimatum" to the populist government to call early elections after months of student-led strikes across the country, in Belgrade, on June 28, 2025. Anti-graft protests have rocked the Balkan nation since November when 16 people were killed in the northern city of Novi Sad by a train station roof collapse, a tragedy widely blamed on entrenched corruption. For over half a year, students have blockaded universities and organised large demonstrations around the country, demanding a transparent investigation into the tragedy with their focus shifting after little action from authorities to call for early parliamentary elections. (Photo by OLIVER BUNIC / AFP) (Photo by OLIVER BUNIC/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Ukraine Reports Record Russian Missile and Drone Attack
item.description: Ukraine said Russia fired a record 537 missiles and drones in “massive” overnight attacks.
item.dc:creator: Kateryna Chursina

media:content.media:description: A policeman inspects debris at the bottom of a multi-storey residential building, which was damaged after a Russian drone attack in Odesa on June 28, 2025, amid the Russian invasion of Ukraine. A Russian drone strike on Ukraine's southern port city of Odesa killed two people and wounded 14, including children, local authorities said. Moscow has stepped up drone and missile attacks on Ukraine and peace talks initiated by the United States to end the three-year conflict have stalled. (Photo by Oleksandr GIMANOV / AFP) (Photo by OLEKSANDR GIMANOV/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: OLEKSANDR GIMANOV/AFP

item.title: UK Welfare Overhaul Back on Track After Concessions, Minister Says
item.description: The UK government expressed confidence it can win a crucial parliamentary vote of its disputed flagship welfare reform policy following a U-turn by Prime Minister Keir Starmer.
item.dc:creator: Shiyin Chen, Naomi Tajitsu

media:content.media:description: Wes Streeting, UK health secretary, departs following a cabinet meeting ahead of the presentation of the spending review in London, UK, on Wednesday, June 11, 2025. UK Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves will defend her fiscal choices and trumpet billions of pounds of infrastructure investment in the UK spending review on Wednesday, as Keir Starmer's government seeks to regain momentum after a faltering first year in power.

item.title: France Confident Tariff Deal Can Be Reached Before Deadline
item.description: French finance minister Eric Lombard said the European Union can clinch some form of a trade agreement with the US before a July 9 deadline, when Washington is set to impose a 50% tariff on nearly all EU products.
item.dc:creator: Claudia Cohen

media:content.media:description: Eric Lombard

item.title: Israeli Gas Flows to Egypt Return to Normal as Iran Truce Holds
item.description: Israeli natural gas flows to Egypt returned to normal levels after a truce with Iran allowed the Jewish state to reopen facilities shuttered by the 12-day conflict.
item.dc:creator: Salma El Wardany

item.title: Musk Fumes as Trump Tax Bill Cuts Electric Vehicle Credits
item.description: Elon Musk slammed the US Senate’s latest version of President Donald Trump’s multi-trillion dollar tax bill Saturday, warning that the cuts to electric vehicle and other clean energy credits would be “incredibly destructive” to the country.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Tarabay

media:content.media:description: Elon Musk, chief executive officer of Tesla Inc., during a news conference in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, May 30, 2025. The event gives an opportunity for the president and his largest campaign benefactor to dispel any notion of an acrimonious divorce.

item.title: Chants of 'Death to the IDF' at Glastonbury 'Appalling,' Streeting Says
item.description: Wes Streeting has said chants of "death" to the Israel Defence Forces (IDF) at Glastonbury were "appalling" and that the BBC and festival have "questions to answer".

media:content.media:description: Crowds watch Kneecap performing on the West Holts Stage during the Glastonbury Festival at Worthy Farm in Somerset. Picture date: Saturday June 28, 2025. (Photo by Ben Birchall/PA Images via Getty Images)

item.title: Measures to Ease Inflation Must be Speedy, Says Japan’s Ishiba
item.description: Any measures to ease inflation in Japan must be speedy and shouldn’t impede the government’s ability to fund social services, Japan’s Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba said on Sunday, in a comment reflecting his aversion to sales tax cuts as opposition parties campaign to lower the duty ahead of a key election next month.
item.dc:creator: Sakura Murakami

media:content.media:description: Shoppers cross a street in the Ginza district of Tokyo, Japan, on Friday, April 4, 2025. Japan's cabinet office will release a monthly consumer confidence survey on April 9.

item.title: Korea’s Lee Nominates Finance Minister to Tackle Growth, Trade
item.description: South Korean President Lee Jae-myung nominated Koo Yun-cheol as the next finance minister, turning to a veteran bureaucrat to guide the economy at a time of sluggish growth and mounting trade pressures from the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Heesu Lee, Myungshin Cho

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae Myung, South Korea's president, delivers a speech at the National Assembly in Seoul, South Korea, on Thursday, June 26, 2025. South Korea urgently drafted a supplementary budget to address the "pressing" challenges facing the economy, Lee said. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Israel Emerges Stronger From Iran War, But Risks Blowback
item.description: Over the past two years, Israel has become more militarily dominant in the Middle East than at any time in its history. But its success has also laid the groundwork for future risks.
item.dc:creator: Peter Martin, Dan Williams

media:content.media:description: Smoke rises from a location north of Tehran, after being targeted by Israel on June 23. Photographer: Elyas/Middle East Images/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Iran Says 71 Dead in Israeli Strike on Tehran Prison This Month
item.description: An Israeli strike this month on Tehran’s Evin prison killed 71 people, Iran’s judiciary said, in one of the deadliest single Israeli attacks on Iranian soil.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla

media:content.media:description: In this picture obtained from the Iranian judiciary's news agency Mizan Online on June 25, 2025, debris are scattered inside the Evin prison complex in Tehran that was hit days ago by an Israeli strike. The Israeli defence minister announced strikes on the prison and other domestic security agencies in Tehran on June 23. (Photo by Mostafa Roudaki / mizanonline / AFP) (Photo by MOSTAFA ROUDAKI/mizanonline/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Taiwan Says ‘Constructive Progress’ Made in US Trade Talks
item.description: Taiwan said it’s made “constructive progress” in a second round of trade talks with the US, which are aimed at avoiding tariffs imposed by President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: John Liu

item.title: Trump Tax Bill Advances in Senate After Vance Pressures Holdouts
item.description: President Donald Trump’s $4.5 trillion tax cut bill prevailed in a crucial Senate test vote after hours of negotiations between Vice President JD Vance and GOP leaders and Republican holdouts.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Steven T. Dennis

media:content.media:description: US Vice President JD Vance at the US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Saturday, June 28, 2025. President Donald Trump’s $4.5 trillion tax cut bill prevailed in a crucial Senate test vote, a sign that Republican leaders are resolving the infighting over portions of the legislation and moving toward meeting a July 4 deadline the president has set for passage.

item.title: Thai Premier Paetongtarn’s Support Slumps in Poll Amid Protest
item.description: Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra’s support has slumped to single digits in an opinion poll as the premier’s popularity reels from a diplomatic scandal.
item.dc:creator: Anuchit Nguyen

media:content.media:description: Paetongtarn Shinawatra Photographer: Valeria Mongelli/Bloomberg

item.title: Senate Advances Trump’s Tax Bill as Holdouts Back Down
item.description: The Senate voted on Saturday to advance President Donald Trump’s $4.5 trillion tax cut package, clearing a hurdle to push the bill toward final passage.
item.dc:creator: Sam Kim (News)

item.title: Trump Dispatches Vance to Hill to Secure GOP Votes for Tax Bill
item.description: Vice President JD Vance and Senate Republican leaders worked late Saturday to persuade reluctant holdouts to back President Donald Trump’s multi-trillion dollar tax and spending bill.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Ari Natter, Erin Durkin

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, June 27, 2025. A Republican plan to cut $250 billion in Medicaid and other health-care spending hit a procedural roadblock in the Senate Thursday, complicating efforts to pass President Donald Trump’s massive tax and spending package. Photographer: Graeme Sloan/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Threatens to Find Tillis Challenger for Key Senate Seat
item.description: Donald Trump signaled he would meet with Republicans interested in challenging Thom Tillis for his Senate seat after the North Carolina Republican opposed the president’s tax bill.
item.dc:creator: Steven T. Dennis, Jamie Tarabay

media:content.media:description: Thom Tillis Photographer: Tierney L. Cross/Bloomberg

item.title: Wind, Solar Credits Face Shorter Phase-Out in New Tax Bill
item.description: Key tax incentives for US wind and solar projects would face a more aggressive phase-out in the Senate’s latest version of President Donald Trump’s spending package.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter

media:content.media:description: The Altamont Pass wind farm past mustard flowers outside Tracy, California, US, on Thursday, April 6, 2023. California Governor Gavin Newsom lifted many of the water-use restrictions he imposed during the state's punishing three-year drought, now that months of intense rains have refilled reservoirs and inundated farm fields.

item.title: Canada Orders Hikvision to Cease Local Operations
item.description: Canadian Industry Minister Melanie Joly said her government ordered Hikvision Canada to cease all operations in the country and close its business.
item.dc:creator: Yi Wei Wong

media:content.media:description: Surveillance cameras manufactured by Hangzhou Hikvision Digital Technology Co. are mounted on a post at a testing station near the company's headquarters in Hangzhou, China, on Tuesday, May 28, 2019. Hikvision, which is controlled by the Chinese government, is one of the leaders in the market for surveillance technology, with cameras that can produce sharp, full-color images in fog and near-total darkness. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: South Africa’s DA Stays in Coalition; to Boycott Dialogue
item.description: South Africa’s fractious coalition government survived after the second-largest party opted against leaving following its ultimatum to President Cyril Ramaphosa for firing one of its members from his executive, while saying it will boycott his national dialogue.
item.dc:creator: S'thembile Cele, Paul Vecchiatto

item.title: Court Fans Fear of State Patchwork in Birthright Citizenship
item.description: A US Supreme Court ruling is stoking fears that the babies of many noncitizen parents could be treated differently depending on the state in which they’re born, as legal challenges unfold against President Donald Trump’s order ending birthright citizenship.
item.dc:creator: Madlin Mekelburg, Alicia A. Caldwell

media:content.media:description: The US Supreme Court in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, June 27, 2025. The US Supreme Court let President Donald Trump take steps toward restricting automatic birthright citizenship, though the justices held out the possibility lower courts may again thwart him before the rules can take effect.

item.title: Trump Runs Up Supreme Court Winning Streak, Amassing More Power
item.description: The US Supreme Court’s just-completed term had a clear winner: President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump speaks during a news conference at the White House in Washington on Friday. Photographer: Allison Robbert/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Turns on ‘Nice’ Carney With Canadian Tech Tax Ultimatum
item.description: It had all been going so well.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Seal

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump, right, and Mark Carney. Photographer: Francis Chung/Politico/Bloomberg

item.title: Public Land Sales Return in Scaled-Back Form in Trump Tax Bill
item.description: A new version of a plan to sell vast tracts of public lands to help pay for President Donald Trump’s massive package of tax cuts has been added back into the Senate’s latest version of the package.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter

media:content.media:description: Cars drive up Provo Canyon in the Uinta-Wasatch-Cache National Forest outside Provo, Utah, US, on Tuesday, June 24, 2025. Senator Mike Lee plans to forge ahead with a proposal to sell off as much as 3 million acres of public lands in the GOP tax-and-spending bill, after the Senate parliamentarian said the provision’s current language violates reconciliation rules and cannot be included.

item.title: China Steps Up Flood Aid as Threat of Extreme Rains Loom
item.description: China rolled out new measures to better compensate residents affected by flood diversion efforts, as a warming climate heightens the threat of extreme rains and devastating deluges.
item.dc:creator: Mary Hui

media:content.media:description: This photo shows an aerial view of damaged buildings and debris in the aftermath of flooding in Congjiang, in southwestern China's Guizhou province on June 25, 2025. Six people have died from floods inundating China's Guizhou province, state media said on June 26, 2025, after more than 80,000 people were driven from their homes this week. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT (Photo by STR/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Protesters Rally in Bangkok to Demand Premier’s Resignation
item.description: Thousands of Thai protesters rallied in Bangkok on Saturday to demand the resignation of Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra, as the fallout continued from her controversial phone call with former Cambodian leader Hun Sen.
item.dc:creator: Anuchit Nguyen

media:content.media:description: Protesters during a demonstration in Bangkok on June 28. Photographer: Valeria Mongelli/Bloomberg

item.title: Germany’s Window of Opportunity Is Wide Open But Not for Long
item.description: Chancellor Friedrich Merz needs to move fast before headwinds derail his turnaround plans.
item.dc:creator: Michael Nienaber, Kamil Kowalcze

media:content.media:description: Merz’s spending package has potential to add more than €400 billion to Germany’s annual output by 2030.

item.title: Labour’s ‘Starmtroopers’ Mount a Rebellion Against Their Leader
item.description: Keir Starmer’s landslide UK general election win last July delivered to the House of Commons what was supposed to be a hand-picked army of loyalists molded in his image, a cadre that earned the moniker “Starmtroopers.” As the prime minister’s first anniversary in power approaches next week, the troops have mutinied, and some now have him and his chancellor in their sights.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham

media:content.media:description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer

item.title: California Regulator Wants to Pause Newsom Refinery Profit Cap
item.description: California’s energy market regulator is backing off a plan to place a profit cap on oil refiners in the state.
item.dc:creator: Eliyahu Kamisher, Nathan Risser

media:content.media:description: The Phillips 66 Los Angeles refinery in Wilmington, California, US, on Thursday, March 21, 2024. Phillips 66 is scheduled to release earnings figures on April 26.

item.title: Trump Says He Dropped Plans to Ease Iran Sanctions, Slams Leader
item.description: President Donald Trump said he considered easing sanctions on Iran after a ceasefire but would instead keep economic penalties on the country in place, lashing out at Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei for claiming victory in the war with Israel.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump during a news conference at the White House in Washington, DC, on June 27.
